item.title: rick add a quote by Groucho Marx
item.description: "Outside of a dog, a book is man's best friend. Inside of a dog it's too dark to read." -- Groucho Marx

item.title: rick add a quote by Mark Twain
item.description: "Whenever you find yourself on the side of the majority, it is time to pause and reflect." -- Mark Twain

item.title: rick add a quote by Martin Luther King Jr.
item.description: "Darkness cannot drive out darkness: only light can do that. Hate cannot drive out hate: only love can do that." -- Martin Luther King Jr.

item.title: rick add a quote by Anthony G. Oettinger
item.description: "Time flies like an arrow; fruit flies like a banana." -- Anthony G. Oettinger

item.title: rick add a quote by Groucho Marx
item.description: "The secret of life is honesty and fair dealing. If you can fake that, you've got it made." -- Groucho Marx

item.title: rick add a quote by Groucho Marx
item.description: "I sent the club a wire stating, PLEASE ACCEPT MY RESIGNATION. I DON'T WANT TO BELONG TO ANY CLUB THAT WILL ACCEPT ME AS A MEMBER." -- Groucho Marx

item.title: rick add a quote by Walt Whitman
item.description: "Do I contradict myself? Very well, then, I contradict myself; I am large -- I contain multitudes." -- Walt Whitman

item.title: rick add a quote by Groucho Marx
item.description: "Well, art is art, isn't it? Still, on the other hand, water is water! And east is east and west is west and if you take cranberries and stew them like applesauce they taste much more like prunes than rhubarb does. Now, uh... now you tell me what you know." -- Groucho Marx

item.title: rick add a quote by Groucho Marx
item.description: "Those are my principles, and if you don't like them...well I have others." -- Groucho Marx

item.title: rick add a quote by Leo Durocher
item.description: "Baseball is like church. Many attend, few understand." -- Leo Durocher

item.title: rick add a quote by Roger Angell
item.description: "This was a new recognition that perfection is admirable but a trifle inhuman, and that a stumbling kind of semi-success can be much more warming. Most of all, perhaps, these exultant yells for the Mets were also yells for ourselves, and came from a wry, half-understood recognition that there is more Met than Yankee in every one of us. I knew for whom that foghorn blew; it blew for me." -- Roger Angell
